Subject: Re: [neat] Re: Questions about NEAT for poker
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=44025614; y=l2PMwsK4OTi2vte6GIHgRlO_cH-CU0DAU3W6J25a0bO225Y9uodpTHDRfQ
X-Yahoo-Profile: thomas_haferlach


Intuitively it seems to me that one should be able to abstract from the actual raw hand data. If one has the probability of winning in a showdown against an average hand for the hand one is holding what more information can the actual hand provide? 

Thomas

-------- Original-Nachricht --------
Datum: Fri, 16 Feb 2007 20:58:35 -0500
Von: "Jeff Haynes" <feedyurhed@...>
An: neat@yahoogroups.com
CC: 
Betreff: Re: [neat] Re: Questions about NEAT for poker

> >
> >
> >  I'm not quite sure though if just the probability of winning vs a
> random opponent is enough information about the hand. I assumed it's all one
> needs but maybe there's other important information.
> >
> 
> no, not even close.  I was just giving it as an example of information
> that may be useful (or more useful) beyond just the raw data (e.g. the
> cards in your hands, the community cards, betting history, etc).
> 
> - jeff
> 
> -- 
> ...imagine a puddle waking up one morning and thinking, 'This is an
> interesting world I find myself in, an interesting hole I find myself
> in, fits me rather neatly, doesn't it? In fact it fits me staggeringly
> well, must have been made to have me in it!' This is such a powerful
> idea that as the sun rises in the sky and the air heats up and as,
> gradually, the puddle gets smaller and smaller, it's still frantically
> hanging on to the notion that everything's going to be alright,
> because this world was meant to have him in it, was built to have him
> in it; so the moment he disappears catches him rather by surprise. I
> think this may be something we need to be on the watch out for.
> 
> -- Douglas Adams
